column1: #Text=Microchips placed in dogs are small passive radio emitters about the size of a grain of rice that are injected under the skin above the shoulder blades .

#Text=Each microchip has a unique number , and that number is registered on an official central database along with a description of that dog , the owner 's name , address , and contact phone numbers .
#Text=When a scanner is passed over the microchip , that unique number is picked up and displayed on the scanner .
#Text=Knowing if a dog has a microchip is especially helpful if you find a stray dog and need to trace the owner .
#Text=Look for a tag on the dog 's collar .
#Text=If the dog is wearing a collar take a look to see if it has a specific tag that says the dog is microchipped .
#Text=Microchips are made by different manufacturers , and these companies usually issue a metal tags to place on the dog 's collar to alert interested parties that the dog is chipped .

#Text=The tag is supplied in part to let anyone that finds a dog know that it is chipped in order to scan them but it is also a visual deterrent to potential thieves thinking of stealing the dog , since the dog has permanent ID as belonging to someone else .
#Text=If the dog does not have an official ID tag on their collar , look for a bespoke collar tag bearing wording such as " I am microchipped " or " microchipped .

#Text= Know that this is not the same as a tag engraved with the dog 's name and phone number .

_	_	_	_

#Text=If the scanner is working but has not scanned a microchip after a set period of time it displays the message  no chip found .
